Darrell Long.content: Give a bullet point biography of Darrell Long highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born on July 27, 1943, in Detroit, Michigan.
- Earned his Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of Michigan in 1968.
- Founded the Institute for Advanced Computer Studies (IACS) at the University of Maryland in 1970.
- Developed the first high-performance computing system using magnetic cores, known as the "Maryland Machine."
- Led the development of the NASA's High Performance Computing Facility, which became one of the world's largest supercomputing centers.
- Served as the founding director of IACS until 1995.
- Contributed to the field of parallel processing, developing algorithms that could run efficiently on multiple processors.
- Co-authored several influential papers in computer science, including "The Architecture of a Multiprocessor" and "Parallel Algorithms."

- Co-founder of Digital Signal Processing Inc., an early pioneer in real-time DSP technology.
- Contributed significantly to the field of speech recognition through research at AT&T Laboratories.
- Developed algorithms for automatic speech recognition systems that were widely adopted in consumer electronics.
- Named one of the "Top Ten Most Influential People in Computing" by IEEE Spectrum magazine in 2014.
- Honored with the IEEE Computer Society's Charles Babbage Award for Contributions to Digital Signal Processing Technology in 2006.
- Served on numerous advisory boards and panels related to emerging technologies in computing and communications.```

- **Philanthropy**: Founder of The Foundation For Information Technology Education, which aims to increase access to technology education in underserved communities

J\u00fcrg Gutknecht.content: Give a bullet point biography of Jürg Gutknecht highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- **Education**: Doctorate in Computer Science from ETH Zurich (Swiss Federal Institute of Technology)
- **Professional Career**:
  - Joined the Swiss National Supercomputing Centre (CSCS) as an Associate Member in 1997
  - Became a Senior Member of CSCS in 2004
  - Held various leadership positions within the organization, including Director for Research & Development (2013–2015), Director for Scientific Computing (2015–2016), and Executive Board Member (since 2016)
- **Research Contributions**:
  - Led the development of the Piz Daint supercomputer at CSCS, which is one of the world's fastest supercomputers
  - Contributed to the design and implementation of high-performance computing systems for scientific research
  - Co-authored several influential papers on parallel computing and distributed systems
- **Achievements**:
  - Awarded the ACM SIGARCH Gordon Bell Prize in 2018 for his role in advancing supercomputing technology
  - Recognized as a leader in the field of computational science and engineering
  - Continuously involved in shaping the future of supercomputing through strategic planning and innovation efforts

Stephen R. Bourne.content: Give a bullet point biography of Stephen R. Bourne highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born on October 10, 1945, in Cambridge, England
- Graduated from University College London with a degree in Mathematics and Computer Science in 1967
- Conducted research at the National Physical Laboratory (NPL) in Teddington, UK during his PhD studies, focusing on algorithms for computing factorizations
- In 1972, joined IBM Research in Yorktown Heights, New York, where he began working on the development of Unix operating system's shell scripting language
- Developed the first interactive compiler for Unix systems in 1980, which greatly enhanced software development efficiency
- Created the "B" programming language in 1983, designed to be more efficient than its predecessors while still being compatible with existing Unix tools
- Co-authored the widely used Unix manual pages, including the "The Unix Programming Environment" book, published in 1984
- Served as Vice President of Software Engineering at Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC), leading projects that contributed to DEC's success in the market
- Contributed significantly to the evolution of Unix, influencing many aspects of modern computing infrastructure
- Passed away on April 11, 2015, leaving behind a legacy of innovation and technological advancement in the field of computer science.

Here are some bullet point biographies of Stephen R. Bourne given by other agents: 

 Agent response: ```- Born on January 19, 1947, in Sydney, Australia.
- Earned his Bachelor's degree from the University of Western Australia in 1968.
- Focused his studies at the University of Melbourne in 1969.
- Graduated with a Master's degree in Computer Science in 1970.
- Joined IBM in 1972, where he began working on operating systems development.
- Contributed to the creation of Unix, which became one of the most widely used operating systems in the world.
- Developed the first compiler for the Unix programming language in 1975.
- Created the C shell (csh) in 1983, which is still widely used today for interactive command-line interfaces.
- Served as Vice President of Software Development at IBM in 1985.
- His work has significantly influenced the field of computer science, particularly in the areas of operating systems and compilers.```

- Died on March 25, 2015 in San Francisco, California```

Steven Rudich.content: Give a bullet point biography of Steven Rudich highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born in 1965 in New York City.
- Studied at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) where he earned his Ph.D. in Computer Science in 1990.
- Conducted postdoctoral research at the University of California, Berkeley before joining Stanford University's Department of Electrical Engineering/Computer Science in 1994.
- Co-authored the influential paper "On the Complexity of Noninteractive Zero-Knowledge Proofs" with Oded Goldreich in 1997, which introduced the notion of noninteractive zero-knowledge proofs.
- Developed the concept of "non-malleable cryptography," an important theoretical framework for secure computation, with co-author Yael Tauman Kalai in 2001.
- Led a team that developed efficient constructions of non-malleable codes and protocols, contributing significantly to the field of information security.
- Awarded the Gödel Prize in 2008 for his work on non-malleable coding theory.
- Currently holds the position of Professor at the Center for Applied Mathematics at Cornell University.

David S. Johnson.content: Give a bullet point biography of David S. Johnson highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- **1947**: Born in Chicago, Illinois, USA.

- **1968**: Graduated from the University of Michigan with a Bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering.

- **1970s**: Started his academic career at Stanford University, where he earned his Ph.D. in Computer Science.

- **1975**: Joined IBM Research Division, contributing significantly to AI research there.

- **1982**: Founded the Center for Experimental Algorithms (CEA) at Carnegie Mellon University.

- **1983**: Developed the first version of the CEA framework, which became widely used in algorithmic design and analysis.

- **1985**: Created the first implementation of the CEA framework on Unix systems.

- **1986**: Collaborated with Larry Wexler to develop the ALGOL-based programming language called "AlgolW," which was designed to facilitate the development of algorithms using high-level languages.

- **1987**: Co-authored "The Art of Prolog" with Peter Norvig, which introduced the concept of logic programming and influenced many subsequent works in this field.

- **1989**: Directed the creation of the PLT Scheme project, an environment for implementing functional programming languages that included features like macros and continuations.

- **1990**: Contributed to the development of the Common Lisp Object System (CLOS), which is still widely used today in object-oriented programming.

- **1995**: Established the Computer Science Department at Rutgers University.

- **2000s**: Continued his work on algorithmic design and contributed to the field through various publications and collaborations.

- **2010**: Passed away in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA, leaving behind a significant legacy in computer science.

John George Kemeny.content: Give a bullet point biography of John George Kemeny highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- **Education**: Received his B.S. in Mathematics from Dartmouth College in 1947.
- **Early Career**: Worked at the RAND Corporation where he developed mathematical models for weapons systems.
- **Innovations**: Co-developed BASIC (Beginner's All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code) with Thomas Kurtz while teaching at Dartmouth College.
- **Impact on Education**: Introduced computers into college classrooms through BASIC, revolutionizing how programming was taught.
- **Leadership Roles**: Served as President of Dartmouth College from 1968 to 1972.
- **Academic Contributions**: Wrote several textbooks including "Computer Science: An Overview" which is still widely used today.
- **Later Achievements**: Became a professor emeritus at Dartmouth after retiring in 1983 but continued to influence computing education until his death in 2009.

- **Professional Career**:
  - Worked at Bell Labs (1968–1973) where he contributed to the development of early computer networks.
  - Joined the Department of Computer Science at the University of Virginia (1974–1982), where he taught and conducted research on distributed computing systems.
  - Developed the concept of "distributed databases" while working at IBM Research (1982–1984).
  - Served as a Professor of Computer Science at the University of California, San Diego (1984–1990), contributing significantly to the field of parallel computing.
  - Became a full professor at the University of California, Santa Barbara (1990–present), focusing on the design and implementation of high-performance computer architectures.

  - Co-authored several influential papers in the fields of distributed computing and parallel processing.
  - Designed and implemented the first parallel database management system, which demonstrated the feasibility of using computers for large-scale data processing.
  - Contributed to the development of the Berkeley Parallel File System, a precursor to modern parallel file systems.
  - Developed the concept of the "Moore's Law" for computer hardware, emphasizing that the performance of microprocessors doubles approximately every two years.

Charles H. Moore has made significant contributions to the advancement of computer science through his pioneering work in distributed computing, parallel processing, and the design of efficient computer architectures.```

Madhu Sudan.content: Give a bullet point biography of Madhu Sudan highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born in India in 1972, Madhu Sudan is an Indian-American computer scientist known for his work on computational complexity theory.
- He received his Ph.D. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) under the supervision of Michael Sipser in 1998.
- His doctoral thesis, "On the Power of Resolution," was highly influential in advancing the field of proof complexity.
- Sudan has made significant contributions to the understanding of computational hardness and its implications.
- In 2015, he became a professor at MIT, continuing his research in theoretical computer science.
- Sudan's work includes foundational papers that have shaped the study of computational complexity, including "The Complexity of Formula Evaluation" (1993).
- He has also contributed to the development of quantum computing concepts, particularly in the context of post-quantum cryptography.
- Sudan is recognized for his ability to bridge theoretical computer science with practical applications, influencing various fields beyond pure mathematics.

Here are some bullet point biographies of Madhu Sudan given by other agents: 

 Agent response: ```- Born in Bangalore, India on October 29, 1968
- Graduated from the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Bombay with a Bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering
- Received his Ph.D. in Computer Science from Stanford University in 1994 under the supervision of Michael F. Peshkin
- Founded the Center for Research in Cryptography at MIT in 2003, where he has been leading research efforts in cryptography and coding theory
- Known for his work in computational complexity theory and algorithm design
- Made significant contributions to the development of algorithms that have improved the efficiency of various computing tasks
- Co-authored several influential papers in the field of information theory, including "The Capacity of Communication Channels"
- Has received numerous awards and honors for his research, including the ACM SIGACT Distinguished Service Award and the IEEE Information Theory Society Paper Award
- Continues to be an active researcher and professor at MIT, contributing to advancements in both theoretical and applied aspects of computer science```

- Developed an algorithm called "Sudan's Algorithm" for decoding Reed-Solomon codes, which was later adopted by Apple Inc.
- Co-authored the book "Introduction to Coding Theory" published by Cambridge University Press

- Continues to be an active researcher in the field of information theory and coding theory

Ian Goldberg.content: Give a bullet point biography of Ian Goldberg highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born in Toronto, Canada on April 29, 1964.
- Earned his Ph.D. from the University of Waterloo in Computer Science in 1990.
- Focused on developing secure protocols for distributed systems.
- Coined the term "cryptoanarchy" to describe a society where cryptography is used to govern access to services.
- Invented the concept of "zero-knowledge proofs" which allow one party to prove to another that they know something without revealing what it is.
- Developed the first public-key infrastructure (PKI) based on elliptic curves.
- Created the Secure Boot protocol, now widely adopted in operating systems like Windows 8.
- Served as a professor at the University of Toronto from 1997 to 2015.
- Received numerous awards for his work including the ACM Turing Award in 2013, often described as the Nobel Prize of computing.

Here are some bullet point biographies of Ian Goldberg given by other agents: 

 Agent response: ```- Born on November 14, 1963, in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.
- Graduated from the University of British Columbia with a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science.
- Conducted his Ph.D. research at Stanford University under the supervision of Dan Kaminsky.
- In 1998, co-invented the "XSS" (Cross-Site Scripting) attack, which is now widely recognized as one of the most significant vulnerabilities in web applications.
- Has been a key figure in the development of various cryptographic algorithms and protocols, including the use of elliptic curve cryptography for public-key encryption.
- Served as a member of the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), contributing to the standardization of secure communication protocols such as TLS (Transport Layer Security).
- Co-authored several influential papers in the field of computer security, including "The Heartbleed Bug: A Threat to HTTPS?" in 2014.
- Currently holds positions at the University of Waterloo and Microsoft Research, focusing on cybersecurity and software security.
- Received numerous awards and honors throughout his career, including the ACM SIGSAC Outstanding Paper Award in 2005 and the IEEE Computer Society's Computer Pioneer Award in 2017.```

 Agent response: ```- **Education:** 
  - Bachelor's degree in Computer Science from the University of Waterloo

- **Career Highlights:**
  - Founded the Canada Research Chair in Cybersecurity at the University of Toronto
  - Developed the first public-key cryptosystem based on elliptic curves, now known as ECC (Elliptic Curve Cryptography)
  - Co-authored "The Art of Computer Programming" series, widely regarded as one of the most influential texts in computer science
  - Served as an advisor to multiple government agencies and international organizations regarding cybersecurity
  - Created the concept of "software obsolescence" and advocated for software security and privacy
  - Contributed significantly to the development of blockchain technology, particularly in relation to smart contracts and decentralized systems
  - Collaborated on projects involving biometric authentication technologies and secure computing environments

- **Awards and Recognition:**
  - Member of the Order of Ontario
  - Fellow of the Royal Society of Canada
  - Recipient of the ACM Turing Award (the highest distinction in computer science) in recognition of his pioneering work in cryptography and computational complexity
  - Named one of the top 100 innovators under 35 by MIT Technology Review
  - Honored with the Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Medal for services to information technology and innovation in Canada```

James H. Wilkinson.content: Give a bullet point biography of James H. Wilkinson highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born in Scotland in 1905.
- Studied mathematics at the University of Edinburgh before moving to the United States for further education.
- Received his Ph.D. from Harvard University in 1934.
- Contributed significantly to the field of numerical analysis during World War II.
- Developed the Wilkinson's polynomial, which is used to test the accuracy of iterative methods for solving systems of linear equations.
- Worked on early computers like the UNIVAC I, contributing to its development.
- Was part of the team that built one of the first digital electronic computers, the Electronic Numerical Integrator And Computer (ENIAC).
- His work influenced the design of many subsequent computing machines.
- Served as an advisor to the U.S. Department of Defense on computer-related matters.
- Retired from IBM in 1967 after a career spanning over four decades.
- Has been recognized with numerous awards throughout his career, including the National Medal of Science in 1982.

James H. Wilkinson was born on October 22, 1905, in Glasgow, Scotland. He pursued higher studies at the University of Edinburgh, where he earned his B.Sc. in Mathematics in 1926. Following this, he moved to the United States, earning his Ph.D. from Harvard University in 1934.

Wilkinson's academic journey continued with him joining the Royal Navy during World War II. Initially working on naval operations, he later became involved in the development of computing machines for military purposes. Post-war, he embarked on a distinguished academic career, serving as a professor at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (now UMIST), which has since evolved into the University of Manchester.

During his time at UMIST, Wilkinson developed groundbreaking algorithms and contributed significantly to the field of numerical analysis. He is particularly known for creating the Wilkinson's polynomial, which serves as a benchmark for testing the accuracy of iterative methods for solving systems of linear equations.

Throughout his career, Wilkinson played a crucial role in the early days of computer technology. He was closely associated with early computers such as the UNIVAC I and the Electronic Numerical Integrator And Computer (ENIAC). His work had a profound impact on the evolution of these devices, making them more efficient and reliable.

Wilkinson also collaborated extensively with other researchers and engineers across various projects related to numerical analysis and scientific computing. His efforts were instrumental in improving computational efficiency and advancing the state-of-the-art in these fields.

Over the course of his career, Wilkinson received numerous accolades and honors. In recognition of his outstanding contributions, he was awarded the National Medal of Science in 1982. Throughout his long-standing career spanning nearly half a century, he served as an advisor to the U.S. Department of Defense on computer-related matters.

After retiring from IBM in 1967, Wilkinson continued to be active in academia and research, leaving behind a legacy of innovation and influence in the field of computing science.

---

Brian Cantwell Smith.content: Give a bullet point biography of Brian Cantwell Smith highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- **1946**: Born in New York City to American parents.
- **1963**: Earns his PhD from the University of California, Berkeley, under the supervision of Claude Shannon.
- **1972**: Founding Editor-in-Chief of Communications of the ACM (CACM).
- **1980s**: Develops the concept of "reconfigurable computing" which allows computers to be reprogrammed after manufacture.
- **1985**: Writes "The Computer as an Extended Mind", challenging traditional notions of computation and cognition.
- **1986**: Establishes the Center for Reconfigurable Computing at Stanford University.
- **1991**: Publishes "Principles of Distributed Systems", which introduces principles for designing distributed systems.
- **1995**: Founds the Computer Science Department at the University of California, Santa Cruz.
- **1996**: Co-founds the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI) and serves as its first President.
- **2001**: Awarded the Turing Award for his work on the foundations of artificial intelligence and the theory of distributed systems.
- **2005**: Receives the IEEE Computer Society's Distinguished Service Award.
- **2012**: Retires but continues to contribute through writing and mentoring young researchers.
- **2016**: Dies at age 70, leaving behind a legacy that has influenced fields such as AI, robotics, and distributed systems.

Lotfi Zadeh.content: Give a bullet point biography of Lotfi Zadeh highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born on September 17, 1921, in Tehran, Iran.
- Received his Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in 1950 under advisor Marvin Minsky.
- Focused on developing mathematical theories for fuzzy logic, which he introduced in 1965.
- Coined the term "fuzzy set" to describe sets that have degrees of membership rather than strict inclusion or exclusion.
- Created the concept of fuzzy automata and developed fuzzy control theory, leading to advancements in artificial intelligence and robotics.
- Developed the Zadeh's Lemma, which is crucial in fuzzy set theory and has applications in various fields including image processing and pattern recognition.
- Contributed significantly to the field of engineering education through the creation of the first undergraduate course in fuzzy systems at the University of California, Berkeley.
- In 2008, he received the IEEE Computer Society Medal for outstanding lifetime achievement in computing and information sciences.
- Passed away on October 3, 2014, in San Francisco, California.

---

Lotfi Thabit Zadeh was born on May 17, 1921, in Tehran, Iran. He fled to the United States in 1943 during World War II due to political unrest in Iran. After receiving his Ph.D. from MIT in 1950 under the guidance of Norbert Wiener, he continued his research and teaching.

Zadeh contributed significantly to the field of fuzzy logic, which he introduced in 1965. He co-founded the Fuzzy Set Theory, a mathematical framework for dealing with imprecise or uncertain information. His work expanded the scope of mathematical modeling beyond binary concepts, paving the way for more nuanced problem-solving methods.

In 1973, he created the first fuzzy inference system, a key development in artificial intelligence. This system was instrumental in advancing the field of artificial intelligence and its applications in various industrial settings. Zadeh also played a pivotal role in establishing the Department of Industrial Engineering at the University of California, Berkeley, where he later served as Chair.

Throughout his career, Zadeh received numerous prestigious awards, including the Turing Award (which is often considered the Nobel Prize of Computing) in 1988. His contributions were recognized globally, and he founded the Fuzzy Systems Society in 1973.

Zadeh passed away on October 17, 2000, after battling Alzheimer's disease.

---

Joseph Sifakis.content: Give a bullet point biography of Joseph Sifakis highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born in 1937 in Athens, Greece.
- Graduated from the University of California at Berkeley with a degree in Electrical Engineering.
- Founded his own company, Sifakiscs Inc., focusing on artificial intelligence research.
- Developed the first expert system called MYCIN for diagnosing infections in blood cultures.
- Co-authored "The Art of Computer Programming" (Volumes I–IV), one of the most influential texts in computer science education.
- Invented the concept of an abstract machine, which is fundamental to modern programming languages.
- Created the System R database management system, influencing later relational database designs.
- Contributed significantly to the field of computational linguistics through work on natural language processing.
- Won numerous awards for his scientific contributions, including the Turing Award in 1982.
- Retired from academia but continues to be involved in AI research and development.
- Has authored over 40 books and more than 600 articles on various aspects of computing and artificial intelligence.
- Maintains active involvement in professional organizations and serves as an advisor to several tech companies.
- His legacy includes mentoring many students who have gone on to become leaders in technology and academia.

John Mauchly.content: Give a bullet point biography of John Mauchly highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born on June 21, 1906, in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
- Graduated from the University of Pennsylvania with a degree in electrical engineering in 1930.
- Founded the Moore School of Electrical Engineering at the University of Pennsylvania in 1948.
- Invented the first digital electronic computer, ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator And Computer) in 1945–1947.
- Contributed to the development of the EDVAC (Electronic Discrete Variable Automatic Computer).
- Co-founded the Moore Corporation in 1957, which became one of the world's largest semiconductor manufacturers.
- Served as President of the Institute for Defense Analysis during the Cold War era.
- Received numerous awards throughout his career, including the National Medal of Technology in 1967.

Volker Strassen.content: Give a bullet point biography of Volker Strassen highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born on February 17, 1946, in Vienna, Austria.
- Graduated from the University of Vienna in mathematics and computer science in 1968.
- Taught at several institutions including the University of California, Berkeley (1975–1980) and Princeton University (1980–1992).
- Famed for his work in computational complexity theory.
- Invented the Strassen algorithm in 1969 while working at IBM's Thomas J. Watson Research Center.
- Known for developing the first practical fast matrix multiplication algorithm using the divide-and-conquer approach, which significantly improved upon earlier methods.
- His research has had a profound impact on the field of algorithms, particularly in areas such as linear algebra and numerical analysis.
- Awarded numerous honors, including being elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 1993.
- Contributed to the development of quantum computing concepts through his theoretical work.
- Retired from academia in 1992 but continues to be an influential figure in the field of computer science.

Here are some bullet point biographies of Volker Strassen given by other agents: 

 Agent response: ```- Born on December 28, 1947, in Vienna, Austria
- Graduated from the University of Vienna with a degree in mathematics in 1969
- Joined IBM Research in 1970 as a research associate
- Invented the fast matrix multiplication algorithm (Strassen's algorithm) in 1971, which significantly improved computational efficiency for large-scale matrix operations
- Contributed to the development of parallel algorithms and distributed computing techniques
- Co-authored influential papers such as "Algorithms in Probabilistic Number Theory" (1975)
- Received the ACM Turing Award in 1989 for his pioneering work in computational complexity theory and its applications to computer science
- Retired from IBM in 1993 but continued to be active in academia and industry, focusing on theoretical computer science and algorithm design
- Has been recognized with numerous awards including honorary degrees and fellowships from prestigious institutions around the world```

- Earned his PhD from the University of Bonn in Germany in 1970 under the supervision of Herbert Brandes.
- Founded the Laboratory for Algorithmic Theories at ETH Zurich in 1975.
- Known for developing Strassen's algorithm in 1971, which significantly improved matrix multiplication algorithms.
- Contributed to the field of computational complexity theory, particularly in proving that matrix multiplication cannot be done faster than O(n^2.8) using circuits of polynomial size.
- Awarded the Turing Award in 1986 for "fundamental contributions to theoretical computer science."
- His work has had a profound impact on the development of parallel computing and distributed systems.
- Continued his research career until he retired in 2013.
- Active in various professional organizations and served as an advisor to several leading universities worldwide.
- Received numerous other awards and honors throughout his career, including the ACM A.M. Turing Award (the highest honor in computer science), the Pour le Mérite for Science and Art (Germany’s highest civilian award), and the Order of Merit (Austria).```

### Biography of Volker Strassen

**Early Life and Education**

- **Birth:** Volker Strassen was born on December 28, 1946, in Vienna, Austria.
- **Education:** He graduated from the University of Vienna with a degree in mathematics in 1969.

**Career Beginnings and Early Contributions**

- **IBM Research:** Strassen joined IBM Research in 1970 as a research associate.
- **Invention of Strassen's Algorithm:** In 1971, Strassen developed the first practical fast matrix multiplication algorithm, known as Strassen's algorithm. This groundbreaking work significantly improved computational efficiency for large-scale matrix operations.

**Theoretical Contributions**

- **Computational Complexity Theory:** Strassen made fundamental contributions to computational complexity theory, proving that matrix multiplication cannot be done faster than \(O(n^{2.8})\) using circuits of polynomial size.
- **Parallel Algorithms and Distributed Computing:** He also contributed to the field of parallel algorithms and distributed computing techniques, enhancing the scalability of computations across multiple processors.

**Academic Achievements and Recognition**

- **Turing Award:** Strassen received the ACM Turing Award in 1989 for "fundamental contributions to theoretical computer science." This recognition underscores his significant influence and impact in the field.
- **Honors and Fellowships:** Throughout his career, Strassen has been honored with numerous awards and fellowships, including:
  - **National Academy of Sciences (USA):** Elected in 1993.
  - **Order of Merit (Austria):** Recognized for his contributions to science and art.
  - **Pour le Mérite for Science and Art (Germany):** One of the highest civilian awards in Germany.

**Later Career and Legacy**

- **Retirement:** Strassen retired from IBM in 1993 but continued to be actively involved in academia and industry, focusing on theoretical computer science and algorithm design.
- **Professional Organizations:** He has remained active in various professional organizations, serving as an advisor to leading universities worldwide.
- **Additional Awards:** Strassen has received additional accolades such as the ACM A. M. Turing Award (the highest honor in computer science), the Pour le Mérite for Science and Art (Germany’s highest civilian award), and the Order of Merit (Austria).

Volker Strassen's work has profoundly impacted the fields of computational complexity, parallel computing, and distributed systems, leaving a lasting legacy in the history of computer science.

Gast\u00f3n Gonnet.content: Give a bullet point biography of Gastón Gonnet highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born in Buenos Aires, Argentina on August 19, 1952
- Earned his Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of Buenos Aires in 1978
- Made significant contributions to the field of computational complexity theory
- Developed the first polynomial-time algorithm for computing Fibonacci numbers, which has since become known as "Gonnet's algorithm"
- Created the first efficient algorithm for matrix exponentiation, now widely used in various scientific applications
- Contributed to the development of fast Fourier transforms (FFT) algorithms, improving the efficiency of signal processing and data analysis
- Co-authored several influential papers in theoretical computer science and cryptography
- Has held academic positions at institutions such as MIT, Stanford, and EPFL
- Served as an advisor or mentor to numerous students who have gone on to make important contributions to computer science
- Is recognized internationally for his work in computational mathematics and theoretical computer science
- Has received several awards for his contributions to these fields, including the ACM Turing Award in 2006 for "fundamental research that led to major advances in computational complexity theory"

Margaret Hamilton.content: Give a bullet point biography of Margaret Hamilton  highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character.

- Born in 1936 in Cambridge, Massachusetts, USA
- Graduated from Smith College with a degree in mathematics and physics in 1958
- Worked at MIT Lincoln Laboratory during the Cold War era
- Led the team that developed software for Apollo Guidance Computer (AGC)
- Co-authored "Software Requirements" (1970) to help define software requirements
- Created the first high-level language called BASIC (Beginners All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code)
- Founded the Software Engineering Institute at Carnegie Mellon University in 1972
- Served as Chief Scientist at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center from 1984 to 1990
- Won numerous awards including the National Medal of Technology and Innovation in 1996
- Passed away on January 10, 2016, at the age of 79

Here are some bullet point biographies of Margaret Hamilton  given by other agents: 

 Agent response: ```- Born on December 14, 1936, in Burlington, Vermont.
- Graduated from Smith College with a degree in mathematics in 1958.
- In 1960, she received her Ph.D. in electrical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).
- She joined MIT's Lincoln Laboratory in 1967 as a research associate.
- Developed the software for the first operational minicomputer, PDP-10, which was used to control the Apollo Guidance Computer during the lunar landing missions.
- Led the development team that wrote the code for the onboard flight software for NASA's Apollo Command and Service Module, ensuring safe landings and launches.
- Was named Commander-in-Chief of Software Engineering at MIT Lincoln Labs in 1971, overseeing all software projects.
- Co-authored "Software Requirements" with Dr. Thomas J. Kurtz, an influential book in the field of software requirements analysis.
- Served as Chief Engineer of the U.S. Space Shuttle program from 1982 until 1988, developing mission critical systems including the Orbiter Control System and Mission Systems Data Acquisition System.
- Awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1991 for her work in spaceflight software design.
- Died on January 8, 2016, in Newton, Massachusetts, at the age of 79.```
